name: Créer des briefs d'intelligence AI à partir de newsletters avec Gemini, Slack et Notion
description:
Ce modèle n8n traite automatiquement vos newsletters sectorielles et crée des briefs d'intelligence alimentés par l'IA qui filtrent le signal du bruit. Parfait pour les professionnels occupés qui doivent rester informés sans surcharge d'informations, il fournit des insights structurés directement dans Slack tout en enregistrant éventuellement des questions de contenu dans Notion.
## Pour qui est-ce
Des cadres occupés, des chefs de produits et des créateurs de contenu dans des entreprises en croissance qui s'abonnent à plusieurs newsletters sectorielles mais n'ont pas le temps de toutes les lire. Idéal pour les équipes qui doivent repérer des tendances, générer des idées de contenu et partager des insights sélectionnés sans se noyer dans l'information.
## Comment ça fonctionne
Le flux de travail s'exécute quotidiennement pour récupérer des e-mails étiquetés depuis Gmail, combine tout le contenu des newsletters et l'envoie à un agent IA pour une analyse intelligente. L'IA filtre les développements à travers le prisme de votre entreprise spécifique, identifie uniquement les insights opérationnellement pertinents et génère des questions stimulantes pour la création de contenu. Les résultats sont formatés en tant que messages Slack riches utilisant Block Kit, avec une intégration Notion optionnelle pour le suivi des idées de contenu.
## Exigences
- Compte Gmail avec système d'étiquetage des newsletters
- Clé API OpenRouter pour l'analyse IA (coûte environ 0,01 à 0,05 $ par exécution) ou clé API pour un LLM spécifique
- Espace de travail Slack avec autorisations de bot pour la publication de messages
- Compte Notion avec configuration de base de données (optionnel, pour le suivi des questions de contenu)
- Clé API Perplexity (optionnelle, pour des capacités de recherche IA supplémentaires)

## Comment configurer
1 Connectez vos identifiants Gmail, OpenRouter et Slack via le système de gestion des identifiants sécurisé de n8n.
2. Créez une étiquette Gmail pour les newsletters que vous souhaitez analyser et configurez-la dans le nœud "Obtenir des newsletters étiquetées".
3. Mettez à jour l'ID de canal Slack dans le nœud "Envoyer à Slack".

Le modèle est préconfiguré avec des paramètres d'exemple pour les entreprises technologiques, vous pouvez donc l'exécuter immédiatement après la configuration des identifiants.

## Comment personnaliser le flux de travail
- Modifiez le nœud "Configuration" pour correspondre à votre secteur et à votre public - changez les 13 champs prédéfinis, y compris le public cible, le contexte commercial, les filtres de pertinence et les piliers de contenu.
- Ajustez l'expression cron dans le nœud de déclenchement pour votre fuseau horaire.
- Modifiez le code de formatage Slack pour changer l'apparence de la sortie, ou ajoutez des nœuds de destination supplémentaires pour l'e-mail, Teams ou Discord.
- Supprimez les nœuds Notion si vous avez seulement besoin de la sortie Slack.

Le cadre d'analyse IA est entièrement personnalisable via le nœud Configuration, vous permettant de passer de l'accent par défaut sur les entreprises technologiques à n'importe quel secteur, y compris la santé, la finance, le marketing ou le conseil.

nodes.name: Get Labeled Newsletters
nodes.notes: Fetches emails with your specified label from the last 24 hours

nodes.name: Combine All Newsletters
nodes.notes: Combines all newsletter emails into a single item for AI processing

nodes.name: AI Newsletter Analyst
nodes.notes: AI agent that analyzes newsletters and generates insights based on your configuration

parameters.text:
=Analyze today's newsletters and create a comprehensive brief for {{ $('Configuration').item.json.recipient_name }}.

## Context
{{ $('Configuration').item.json.business_context }}

## Task 1: Executive Summary
From today's newsletters, identify 3-5 developments that matter for {{ $('Configuration').item.json.target_audience }}. For each:

**[Development Title]**
- TL;DR: [2-3 sentences explaining what this is about]
- Why this matters: [1-2 sentences on real business impact for your audience]
- Implementation reality: [What it would actually take to adopt this]
- Source: [Newsletter sender name]

Only include developments that pass this test: {{ $('Configuration').item.json.relevance_filter }}

As part of the executive summary, include a short tl;dr that should be maximum of 1-2 sentences summarizing all the developments you extract.

## Task 2: Content-Inspiring Questions
Generate 3-4 questions that could become {{ $('Configuration').item.json.content_platforms }} content. Each question should:
- Connect to real operational challenges
- Bridge technical capability and business reality
- Feel non-obvious but highly relevant

Format:
**Question:** [Concise, thought-provoking question]
**Context:** [1 sentence on why this question matters now, referencing specific newsletter content]
**Relevant Content Pillar:** [name of the content pillar this relates to]

## Task 3: Hidden Patterns
Brief note on any patterns across multiple newsletters that suggest an emerging theme your audience should track.

Remember: Filter aggressively. If something is just "interesting" but not actionable for your specific audience, exclude it. Focus on signal, not noise.

## Content to analyze

Here are the newsletters and their content: {{ 
$json.newsletter.map(item => 
  `Subject: "${item.subject}"
Full content follows:
${item.textAsHtml}`
).join('\\n\\n==========\\n\\n')
}}

options.systemMessage:
=You are an AI intelligence analyst for {{ $('Configuration').item.json.company_name }}, helping to filter the daily flood of newsletters through a specific operational lens.

## Core Context

### Who You Serve
{{ $('Configuration').item.json.target_audience_description }}

### Your Unique Perspective
You view information through three interconnected lenses:
1. **Operational Reality**: How does this actually work in a running business?
2. **Technical Feasibility**: What's required to implement this at scale?
3. **Human Dynamics**: How will teams actually adopt and use this?

### Content Focus Areas
{{ $('Configuration').item.json.content_pillars }}

## Processing Framework

When analyzing newsletters and updates:

### Relevance Filter
INCLUDE information about:
- New capabilities that could change how operations work (not just make them faster)
- Implementation patterns from companies in the {{ $('Configuration').item.json.company_size_range }} range
- Tools or frameworks that bridge technical capability and business operations
- Real implementation case studies (not just press releases)
- {{ $('Configuration').item.json.additional_include_criteria }}

EXCLUDE information about:
- Pure research advances without clear operational application
- Consumer products without business applications
- Generic tool updates that are just feature additions
- {{ $('Configuration').item.json.additional_exclude_criteria }}

### Analysis Depth
For each relevant item, consider:
- What operational problem does this actually solve?
- What would implementing this require (people, process, technology)?
- How does this connect to what {{ $('Configuration').item.json.target_audience }} are already doing?

If needed, and really only in cases where you feel it's required, you can use the Perplexity tool to find additional information. Be efficient in your use.

## Output Requirements

### Executive Summary Structure
- Lead with operational impact, not technical innovation
- Connect developments to specific challenges your audience faces
- Use concrete examples over abstract possibilities
- Maintain calm clarity - no breathless hype
- Maximum 3-5 key developments per day (quality over quantity)
- Keep language free of jargon and accessible
- Go for conciseness while including essential information

### Question Generation Philosophy
Create questions that:
- Bridge the gap between potential and operational reality
- Challenge conventional thinking
- Explore practical implementation tensions
- Address the "how" after others cover the "what"
- Connect capabilities to business outcomes
- Use clear, accessible language without corporate jargon

Questions should feel like they come from someone who has actually worked in this space, not someone theorizing about it.

Remember: Your audience needs insights that are worth their precious mental space during commutes and reflection time.

nodes.name: Daily Morning Trigger
nodes.notes: Runs daily at 8am UTC - adjust timezone as needed

nodes.name: Filter Out Empty Results
nodes.notes: Only proceeds if emails were found

nodes.name: Format for Slack
nodes.notes: Converts AI analysis to rich Slack Block Kit format

nodes.name: Send to Slack
nodes.notes: Sends formatted brief to your Slack channel

nodes.name: OpenRouter Chat Model
nodes.notes: Primary AI model for newsletter analysis

nodes.name: Split Out Questions
nodes.notes: Separates content questions for individual processing

nodes.name: Save Questions to Notion
nodes.notes: Creates Notion pages for each content question (optional)

nodes.name: Perplexity Research Tool
nodes.notes: Optional tool for the AI agent to gather additional context

nodes.name: Structured Output Parser
nodes.notes: Ensures AI output follows the expected JSON structure

nodes.name: Conversation Memory
nodes.notes: Maintains context across multiple AI interactions

nodes.name: Configuration
nodes.notes: 📝 CUSTOMIZE THESE VALUES for your business and use case

assignments.name: recipient_name
assignments.value: Who the brief is for (e.g., "Tech Team")

assignments.name: target_audience
assignments.value: Who you're analyzing for (e.g., "product managers and engineering leaders")

assignments.name: company_size_range
assignments.value: Size of companies you focus on (e.g., "50-200 employee")

assignments.name: relevance_filter
assignments.value: The key question to filter relevant news

assignments.name: content_platforms
assignments.value: Where you'll use insights (e.g., "LinkedIn posts, internal updates")

assignments.name: content_pillars
assignments.value: Your main content focus areas (3 pillars)

assignments.name: additional_include_criteria
assignments.value: Extra things to include in analysis

assignments.name: brief_title
assignments.value: Title for your Slack briefs (e.g., "Tech Intelligence Brief")

parameters.content:
## 🤖 AI-powered Newsletter Intelligence Brief

This n8n template automatically analyzes newsletters you receive and creates an intelligent brief that filters signal from noise. Perfect for busy professionals who need to stay informed without information overload.

## Who's it for
- **Busy executives and founders** who subscribe to industry newsletters but lack time to read them all
- **Content creators and strategists** who need to spot trends and generate content ideas
- **Team leaders** who want to share curated insights with their teams
- **Anyone** who wants AI to help them stay informed efficiently

## How it works
1. **Daily collection**: Automatically fetches emails with your specified label from the last 24 hours
2. **AI analysis**: Uses advanced AI to analyze content through your specific business lens
3. **Intelligent filtering**: Only surfaces developments that meet your relevance criteria
4. **Multi-format output**: Sends formatted briefs to Slack and optionally saves questions to Notion
5. **Content inspiration**: Generates thought-provoking questions for your content creation

## Requirements
- **Gmail account** with newsletters labeled appropriately
- **OpenRouter API key** for AI analysis (costs ~$0.01-0.05 per run)
- **Slack workspace** for receiving briefs
- **Notion account** (optional, for saving content questions)
- **Perplexity API key** (optional, for additional research)

## How to set up
1. **Configure the workflow**: Edit the "Configuration" node with your business details
2. **Set up Gmail**: Create a label for newsletters you want analyzed (Forum instructions: <https://support.google.com/mail/thread/208327636/how-do-i-automatically-label-emails?hl=en|>)
3. **Connect credentials**: Add your API keys and OAuth connections
4. **Customize timing**: Adjust the schedule trigger for your timezone
5. **Test the workflow**: Run manually first to verify everything works

## How to customize
- **Change analysis focus**: Modify the Configuration node values to match your industry/audience
- **Adjust timing**: Edit the cron expression in the trigger node
- **Modify output format**: Update the Slack formatting code node
- **Add more destinations**: Connect additional nodes for email, Teams, etc.
- **Skip Notion**: Remove the Notion nodes if you don't need content question tracking

## Tips for success
- **Be specific** in your relevance criteria to avoid information overload
- **Start with 3-5 newsletters** to test, then add more gradually
- **Review and refine** your configuration based on the quality of results
- **Use consistent labeling** in Gmail for reliable processing

## ⚙️ Setup Steps

### 1. Gmail Setup
- Create a Gmail label (e.g., "AI-Newsletter")
- Apply this label to newsletters you want analyzed
- Select the label from the dropdown options in the node.

### 2. Configure Your Business Context
- Edit the "Configuration" node
- Update all values to match your business, audience, and goals
- Be specific about your relevance criteria

### 3. Connect Credentials
- **Gmail**: OAuth2 connection for email access
- **OpenRouter**: API key for AI models
- **Slack**: Bot token for posting messages
- **Notion**: API key (optional, for questions)
- **Perplexity**: API key (optional, for research)

## 🔧 Required Configuration

### Update These Node Settings:
1. **Get Labeled Newsletters**: Replace "YOUR_GMAIL_LABEL_ID" with your actual Gmail label ID (can simply select it from the dropdown)
2. **Send to Slack**: Replace "YOUR_SLACK_CHANNEL_ID" with your channel ID (can simply select it from the dropdown)
3. **Save Questions to Notion**: Replace "YOUR_NOTION_DATABASE_ID" with your database ID (optional) (can simply select it from the dropdown)
4. **Daily Morning Trigger**: Adjust cron expression for your timezone

### Timezone Note:
The trigger is set to 8am UTC. Adjust as needed:
- 8am Pacific: "0 15 * * *"
- 8am Eastern: "0 12 * * *"
- 8am GMT: "0 8 * * *"

## 🚨 Important Notes

### Security
- Never hardcode API keys in nodes
- Use n8n's credential system

### Costs
- OpenRouter: ~$0.01-0.05 per analysis
- Perplexity: ~$0.01 per research query
- Other services: Free tiers available

### Customization
- Start with the Configuration node
- Test with a few newsletters first
- Adjust prompts based on your results
- The AI will improve with clear instructions

data.details: The Code node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow.

The Filter node can be used to filter items based on a condition. If the condition is met, the item will be passed on to the next node. If the condition is not met, the item will be omitted. Conditions can be combined together by AND(meet all conditions), or OR(meet at least one condition).
